title: Encouraging the transfer of knowledge
segmentation: Came.
To the last session of this one day final seminar.
We have four last presentations to do.
And as the first speaker, I would like to invite Mr. Steve Phillips.
The Secretary General of Pearl.
And the person responsible, even guilty from the positive point of the word.
For many activities that are happening in this area and also about what?
No no, not not anymore no need.
So he is one of the key persons who can tell you a lot about encouragement and transfer of knowledge.
Steve please.
Thank you very much, Alex.
It's it's a bit worrying when you say I'm responsible 'cause it kind of means.
I have to take the blame for a lot of these activities anyway.

I'm going to give a short presentation 'cause I'm not going to take your time because you want to hear from Neil and from Bill about all of the other activities, but I just wanted to take a short time.
A moment really to reflect on where we are with arch is and how we to artisan spends and how we take this forward.
And this is fairly generic as it applies to a lot of projects and a lot of the activities we're trying to encourage.
1st, for those of you on, I don't know how many of you don't know I'm I want to highlight the Members and associates of Furlan how we're trying to mobilize.
If I can take responsibility for this to try to mobilize all of the resource is of these to try and get the message out from all of these projects, and I think we're all of these partners.
What we're trying to do is to is to use these all as a as a platform to get out the information from the projects to get.
All of their their national stakeholders to know about the activities that are going on.
But of course it's not just them on.
And again I look around the room.
It's all of our partners and many, many partners.
I think we did a list recently of the number of partners in projects we had and it's getting close to 1000.
Now if we look at all of the projects we've got, you know we've got 1000 other organizations that we're working on on all the different projects.
And so our challenge there and our our aim is to get that working cohesively and in a good and strong way.
All all of it is trying to share the knowledge and in.
Hours, the dissemination of knowledge because if I can just dwell on what fools objectives are.
It's it's quite simple really.
I mean through research collaboration.
OK, that's our main aim to provide scientific input to the EU and national government policy on Hwy.
Engineering and Rd transport matters.
OK, that's that's self evident to create and maintain an efficient and safe Rd network in Europe to increase innovation in European road construction on the road using industries.

Again, it's not necessary to support the industries, but it's to make sure that the innovations get out there and actually used because the industries from our very, very narrow perspective as the industries that are the main suppliers.

For most of the road authorities and the national governments and the ministries that are actually doing the work and then something I think that is very, very topical now, perhaps wasn't so topical when this was written almost 20 years ago.
But it's to improve the energy efficiency in highway engineering operations.
Now it's number one on the agenda so you know, we need to come back if you like to our roots and say, well, this is what we said we were going to do at the start and now we will be doing more.
And I was very pleased to hear that some of those elements were taken forward.
Certainly in spends.
And even some of the activities in Arch is as well in terms of how to reduce detours and all these other things.
So all of these things come back to their core at the end.
Anyway, how do we?
How do we achieving our objectives?
I think that's that's self evident that the success in achieving our objectives is defined by what impact we make, how how we get the information out there, and how we use.
It's not defined by how many reports we create, how big the film Knowledge Center is in terms of how many reports is it?
You know we can go around and say we got gigabytes of here.
And if you download it or take lots and lots of CDs, that's pointless.
If no ones using it.
The main name we have to do is to get it out there and get it you.
East of course, one of the challenges we have and that this is a common challenge.
That's that's.

That's why we're always looking at how the structure, if you like the structure of European projects, becomes critical is how within our projects do we reflect the diversity of needs and the diversity of challenges in application for all of the activities we do in terms of, you know?
I think it was addressed in spends.
In particular, you know, if we don't want to be transporting the same aggregate from one side of Europe to the other just because it happens to be the best one to be used on that particular.
So all of these trials you know we have to reflect both in the hopefully both in the project itself, but also in its implementation and all.
The follow-up activities that we have to do in spends two spends three spends for Arch is 10.
Whatever all of those things were, you know, we need to be addressing and how we take those on board.
I want to.
Briefly, talk about the research cycle because we are, to a certain extent in one part of the research cycle.
Now that I call it for Archers and spans, Archers and spends is moving in from execution to implementation, we're very, very firmly in that one you've done the research.
Now how we're going to implement it?
How are we going to?
How are we going to get the knowledge out there?

But I don't want to neglect the other parts of the research cycle because again, the end of a project is always a time to reflect on what was good about the project, both technically, but also in the.
Process, so how do we learn from this from our future research?
How do we learn from this from the future projects that we want to do?
The first one, how did these projects start?
You heard?
Bill mentioned yesterday and I touched on it, it was was was how these projects came for almost from the bottom up need from the needs expressed by the new Member States.
In particular.

Although many of those needs were common to all countries, how they were articulated with the European Commission, how we had lots and lots of meetings and this of course is long long before the project was even even even before we thought the name Archers and spends.
All of these what I would call again knowledge sharing activities were going on trying to better understand what's going on, and I'm sure Neil will report from the US side.
They did exactly the same when they did the sharp program.
So this is a very very important phase and it's almost a continuous phase.
We need to be encouraging.
Then we have the knowledge sharing with the research partners we get into the projects.
How do we coordinate the internal capacity?
How do we get the best people working on it?
How do we address the specific research expertise that's needed to balance that across the whole of the project?

And importantly, and this this is, this is something I think I. I think both projects have perhaps done well, and I think the the projects that are coming onstream now are also doing is better meeting the needs of the problem owners.
You know there there is far more emphasis now.
I think in the projects on outreach on communication on having workshops on getting stakeholder reference groups and all those are activities, so we're not.
Defining a project and then going away in isolation and doing it, but continually talking with the people who will be applying it in the end and helping to shape the research that's been going on.
Because at the end of the day, that's what reduces the barriers to implementation.
And if we don't, don't do that.
The Reese.
Which never will be implemented.
And this is where we deal with the barrels into implement implementation.
I'm not going to dwell too much on this.

'cause I know Alice wants to talk a lot about this in relation to the the certain project and how the certain project will be taken on, but I think there are a number of elements we need to take on board.
One of the most common ones.
And again, I I dwell on the fact that this is a.
A multi multi faceted Europe.
Multifaceted world.
We have still this problem in Europe of the it's not invented here.

You know we we we we continue have projects which have, you know I never widen number of countries involved but then it's only the countries involved that ever end up implementing that work and it's rarely the countries that are not involved that are doing it.
So we need to be addressing that.
We need to be bringing more of the stakeholders from all countries into our projects.
Earlier there are issues and I think we have to think about this serious.
Proof of concept.
Proof of concept.

One of my one of my quotes here is is I was long time ago in involved with an organization that was trying to come up with a research project for looking at how to deal with accidents and they were talking with some consultancy's on how the research project and then they do the before and after study and the cost effectiveness and whatever.
This consultancy organization just looked at it and thought well this is so cheap, will just do it and they went away and they implemented it and it's working very very successfully.
So they didn't bother with before and after studies and whatever.
So we have a they feel like there was almost a breakdown of trust 'cause the researchers were saying, but they haven't proved it.
They haven't done all this or activity to prove that it was it's cost effective and whatever 'cause it was so cheap for the consultancy to actually do it.
So the elements there we need to address translation into standards I think is a very very important one.
And again we've touched on that a number of times and certainly in a number of discussions outside.
And the coffee breaks of how we get this work done.
And translated into standard so we can be taken up in different countries.
And I know Alice is going to talk about the language considerations, 'cause that's a large part of this certain project.
How do we get the knowledge out there in a language that people can understand?
Although I'd put another twist on this because, you know, we often work with other industries.
I mean particularly automotive industry.
And we've been working with them for many many years, and one of the first challenges we had, even if in the meeting we were all speaking English.
We didn't understand each other.
Because they were using a completely different language in terms of how they approach technical problems than we were.
So we almost got to the stage where we said we have to have a Glossary here, you know, an infrastructure automotive translation Glossary to try and understand what's going on.
So that's another challenge.
I think we have to address so they understand our problems and we understand that their problems better because it's the it's the vehicle Rd interaction that is becoming far more critical in.
Future.
So how are we going to get this research?
Let's be concrete how we're going to get this research implemented.
Well, I think you've done a lot of the preaching today, and I hope you'll go out and do more of the preaching.
The explanations.
Yeah, both of those need to be done begging.
I think that's going to be a large part of this project.
How are we going to get some of these things implemented on the road?
And that's why I'm going out there for the do the begging, phoning him up, making sure your Rd directorates are constantly reminded, you know, when are we going to do this trial?
How we're going to do this trial and blow your own trumpet?
I think all of these are different strategies of how we're going to get this research implemented, because without these, you know we could say this.
This is the end of our chosen Spence, and I don't think any of us want this to be the end of Archers and spends.
This should be just the end of the project, but not the end of what we do.

She's going to be talking about certain, so I'm not going to dwell on this, and the tools that we've developed which link very, very strongly already with the arches and spends websites 'cause that was one of the core parts when Alex talked about the the cluster that was one of the core objectives that we had is to get all of the all of the projects.
All the projects hosted on a single website, so all of the information is easily exchanged between the projects an it's maintained for perpetuity.
There is no chance I would say.
Categorically, there is no chance that the arches and spends websites will close down tomorrow, as you often found with other projects.
These sites will be there for years and years in the future, and we hope that people continue to use them for years and years in the future.
So if.
I can say and end word as I say at the projects may be finishing, but I don't see the work stopping here and I hope you will agree.
I hope that you all agree.
Maybe we should have a charter, you know an arch is spend the libyana commitment.
You know we have a commitment to implement this research and get on with it.
So let's all support the implementation of research.
Let's share the knowledge about learning what has worked and what hasn't worked, and I personally I look forward to hearing an update in a year.
Studious about what's happened with Archers and spends again.
I don't want these projects to be, you know, just history and we see them on a list in the future and say, oh, I remember The Archers and spends project.
We had a nice workshop in Lubiana and that was it.
These are projects there should be feeding through for years and years.
I mean, our Alex has already mentioned, I think a number of people mentioned Samaris and others.
You can see how projects almost gaining mythology.
You know this sets the Samaris project and how that project fade into the future.
Projects and how it said so.
Let's look at how these projects can do that and encourage all of the sharing and knowledge that we're going to do so.
Thank you for listening.
Our door is always open.
We're always there, ready for communicate, and I see this.
I Alice reminded me yesterday at TRA, so I look forward to seeing you all in TRA.
And perhaps that's when I'll get my update about what you've done in Archers and spends and how we're going to go forward in all this.
So thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Steve for this encourage ING speech.
I hope that people will really remember Spence, an artist after a few years.
